pain_points.title: Fragmented information across multiple languages and platforms
sub_issues: Information scattered across English, Malay, and Chinese platforms with no unified source
Xiaohongshu content (Chinese) inaccessible to Malay and Indian Malaysian demographics
English-language Korean clinic guides mostly target Western audiences, not Southeast Asian context
No Malaysia-specific Korean dermatology guide exists in any language
Lowyat.net and Malaysian forums discuss local dermatology only, not Korean medical tourism

pain_points.title: Difficulty verifying clinic quality and review authenticity
pain_points.title_ko: 클리닉 품질 및 리뷰 진위 확인 어려움
sub_issues: Xiaohongshu clinic recommendations often are paid promotions with planted comments
Korean clinics aggressively target foreigners through advertising but may be less popular among Korean locals
No Malaysian-specific review aggregator for Korean clinics
Foreigner clinics may charge 2-4x more than prices listed on Naver for Korean patients
Google Reviews provide English feedback but limited to international tourists, not comprehensive

pain_points.title: Language barrier during consultation and treatment
sub_issues: Most Korean clinics lack Malay-language support
English support available at some clinics (AMOA, Theme Dermatology, Forena) but not universal
Chinese Malaysian patients can sometimes use Mandarin but Korean clinics primarily offer Chinese staff for mainland Chinese patients
Nuance communication about aesthetic preferences difficult through interpreters
Risk explanation and consent forms may not be fully understood

pain_points.title: Complex booking process without local infrastructure
pain_points.title_ko: 현지 인프라 없는 복잡한 예약 과정
sub_issues: No Malaysia-based Korean medical tourism agency or travel package equivalent to Japan's HIS/JTB
Booking requires navigating multiple apps (UNNI, Kosmedi, Creatrip) designed primarily for other markets
WhatsApp is Malaysia's primary communication tool but not all Korean clinics support it (KakaoTalk preferred)
Coordinating 3-5 day trip logistics (visa, accommodation, clinic schedule) without a local coordinator
Online consultation before travel is not standardized

pain_points.title: No aftercare continuity between Korea and Malaysia
sub_issues: Malaysian dermatologists may refuse follow-up for procedures done in Korea
6-hour flight distance makes return trips for complications costly and impractical
Korean clinics in Malaysia (Ozhean, BBS Clinic) not formally connected to Seoul clinic aftercare networks
Post-treatment skincare guidance may not account for Malaysia's tropical climate differences

pain_points.title: Unclear cost advantage over local premium Malaysian clinics
pain_points.title_ko: 로컬 프리미엄 클리닉 대비 불분명한 가격 메리트
sub_issues: Korean clinics opening in Malaysia (Ozhean, Clinic RX) offer similar treatments locally
When travel, accommodation, and treatment costs are combined, total Korea trip cost may exceed local premium options
Foreigner pricing at Korean clinics can be 2-4x higher than Korean-local prices
Hidden costs: anesthesia, medication, aftercare products billed separately
Currency fluctuation between MYR and KRW adds uncertainty

pain_points.title: Halal and cultural compatibility concerns
sub_issues: Muslim Malay patients need halal-certified skincare products and treatments (no pork-derived ingredients)
Dietary restrictions during post-treatment recovery in Korea
Prayer facilities and halal food availability near Korean clinics
Modest dress requirements during certain procedures
K-beauty brands increasingly offer halal-friendly formulations but not all clinics are aware

pain_points.title: No beginner-friendly entry point for Korean medical tourism
sub_issues: No 'Korean Derm 101' guide targeting Malaysian consumers
Treatment terminology unfamiliar (Potenza, Rejuran, PDRN not mainstream knowledge in Malaysia)
Unclear what can be done locally vs what requires a Korea trip
Lack of cost comparison between Malaysian clinics, Korean clinics in Malaysia, and Korean clinics in Korea
